11// Modified from the Chromium original:
12// src/media/base/sinc_resampler.cc
13
14// Initial input buffer layout, dividing into regions r0_ to r4_ (note: r0_, r3_
15// and r4_ will move after the first load):
16//
17// |----------------|-----------------------------------------|----------------|
18//
19// request_frames_
20// <--------------------------------------------------------->
21// r0_ (during first load)
22//
23// kKernelSize / 2 kKernelSize / 2 kKernelSize / 2 kKernelSize / 2
24// <---------------> <---------------> <---------------> <--------------->
25// r1_ r2_ r3_ r4_
26//
27// block_size_ == r4_ - r2_
28// <--------------------------------------->
29//
30// request_frames_
31// <------------------ ... ----------------->
32// r0_ (during second load)
33//
34// On the second request r0_ slides to the right by kKernelSize / 2 and r3_, r4_
35// and block_size_ are reinitialized via step (3) in the algorithm below.
36//
37// These new regions remain constant until a Flush() occurs. While complicated,
38// this allows us to reduce jitter by always requesting the same amount from the
39// provided callback.
40//
41// The algorithm:
42//
43// 1) Allocate input_buffer of size: request_frames_ + kKernelSize; this ensures
44// there's enough room to read request_frames_ from the callback into region
45// r0_ (which will move between the first and subsequent passes).
46//
47// 2) Let r1_, r2_ each represent half the kernel centered around r0_:
48//
49// r0_ = input_buffer_ + kKernelSize / 2
50// r1_ = input_buffer_
51// r2_ = r0_
52//
53// r0_ is always request_frames_ in size. r1_, r2_ are kKernelSize / 2 in
54// size. r1_ must be zero initialized to avoid convolution with garbage (see
55// step (5) for why).
56//
57// 3) Let r3_, r4_ each represent half the kernel right aligned with the end of
58// r0_ and choose block_size_ as the distance in frames between r4_ and r2_:
59//
60// r3_ = r0_ + request_frames_ - kKernelSize
61// r4_ = r0_ + request_frames_ - kKernelSize / 2
62// block_size_ = r4_ - r2_ = request_frames_ - kKernelSize / 2
63//
64// 4) Consume request_frames_ frames into r0_.
65//
66// 5) Position kernel centered at start of r2_ and generate output frames until
67// the kernel is centered at the start of r4_ or we've finished generating
68// all the output frames.
69//
70// 6) Wrap left over data from the r3_ to r1_ and r4_ to r2_.
71//
72// 7) If we're on the second load, in order to avoid overwriting the frames we
73// just wrapped from r4_ we need to slide r0_ to the right by the size of
74// r4_, which is kKernelSize / 2:
75//
76// r0_ = r0_ + kKernelSize / 2 = input_buffer_ + kKernelSize
77//
78// r3_, r4_, and block_size_ then need to be reinitialized, so goto (3).
79//
80// 8) Else, if we're not on the second load, goto (4).
81//
82// Note: we're glossing over how the sub-sample handling works with
83// |virtual_source_idx_|, etc.
84
85// MSVC++ requires this to be set before any other includes to get M_PI.
86#define _USE_MATH_DEFINES
87
88#include "common_audio/resampler/sinc_resampler.h"
89
90#include <math.h>
91#include <stdint.h>
92#include <string.h>
93
94#include <limits>
95
96#include "rtc_base/checks.h"
97#include "rtc_base/system/arch.h"
98#include "system_wrappers/include/cpu_features_wrapper.h" // kSSE2, WebRtc_G...
99
100namespace webrtc {
101
102namespace {
103
104double SincScaleFactor(double io_ratio) {
105 // |sinc_scale_factor| is basically the normalized cutoff frequency of the
106 // low-pass filter.
107 double sinc_scale_factor = io_ratio > 1.0 ? 1.0 / io_ratio : 1.0;
108
109 // The sinc function is an idealized brick-wall filter, but since we're
110 // windowing it the transition from pass to stop does not happen right away.
111 // So we should adjust the low pass filter cutoff slightly downward to avoid
112 // some aliasing at the very high-end.
113 // TODO(crogers): this value is empirical and to be more exact should vary
114 // depending on kKernelSize.
115 sinc_scale_factor *= 0.9;
116
117 return sinc_scale_factor;
118}
119
120} // namespace
121
122const size_t SincResampler::kKernelSize;
123
124// If we know the minimum architecture at compile time, avoid CPU detection.
125void SincResampler::InitializeCPUSpecificFeatures() {
126#if defined(WEBRTC_HAS_NEON)
127 convolve_proc_ = Convolve_NEON;
128#elif defined(WEBRTC_ARCH_X86_FAMILY)
129 // Using AVX2 instead of SSE2 when AVX2 supported.
130#if !defined(WEBRTC_WEBKIT_BUILD)
131 if (GetCPUInfo(kAVX2))
132 convolve_proc_ = Convolve_AVX2;
133 else
134#endif
135 if (GetCPUInfo(kSSE2))
136 convolve_proc_ = Convolve_SSE;
137 else
138 convolve_proc_ = Convolve_C;
139#else
140 // Unknown architecture.
141 convolve_proc_ = Convolve_C;
142#endif
143}
144
145SincResampler::SincResampler(double io_sample_rate_ratio,
146 size_t request_frames,
147 SincResamplerCallback* read_cb)
148 : io_sample_rate_ratio_(io_sample_rate_ratio),
149 read_cb_(read_cb),
150 request_frames_(request_frames),
151 input_buffer_size_(request_frames_ + kKernelSize),
152 // Create input buffers with a 32-byte alignment for SIMD optimizations.
153 kernel_storage_(static_cast<float*>(
154 AlignedMalloc(sizeof(float) * kKernelStorageSize, 32))),
155 kernel_pre_sinc_storage_(static_cast<float*>(
156 AlignedMalloc(sizeof(float) * kKernelStorageSize, 32))),
157 kernel_window_storage_(static_cast<float*>(
158 AlignedMalloc(sizeof(float) * kKernelStorageSize, 32))),
159 input_buffer_(static_cast<float*>(
160 AlignedMalloc(sizeof(float) * input_buffer_size_, 32))),
161 convolve_proc_(nullptr),
162 r1_(input_buffer_.get()),
163 r2_(input_buffer_.get() + kKernelSize / 2) {
164 InitializeCPUSpecificFeatures();
165 RTC_DCHECK(convolve_proc_);
166 RTC_DCHECK_GT(request_frames_, 0);
167 Flush();
168 RTC_DCHECK_GT(block_size_, kKernelSize);
169
170 memset(kernel_storage_.get(), 0,
171 sizeof(*kernel_storage_.get()) * kKernelStorageSize);
172 memset(kernel_pre_sinc_storage_.get(), 0,
173 sizeof(*kernel_pre_sinc_storage_.get()) * kKernelStorageSize);
174 memset(kernel_window_storage_.get(), 0,
175 sizeof(*kernel_window_storage_.get()) * kKernelStorageSize);
176
177 InitializeKernel();
178}
179
180SincResampler::~SincResampler() {}
181
182void SincResampler::UpdateRegions(bool second_load) {
183 // Setup various region pointers in the buffer (see diagram above). If we're
184 // on the second load we need to slide r0_ to the right by kKernelSize / 2.
185 r0_ = input_buffer_.get() + (second_load ? kKernelSize : kKernelSize / 2);
186 r3_ = r0_ + request_frames_ - kKernelSize;
187 r4_ = r0_ + request_frames_ - kKernelSize / 2;
188 block_size_ = r4_ - r2_;
189
190 // r1_ at the beginning of the buffer.
191 RTC_DCHECK_EQ(r1_, input_buffer_.get());
192 // r1_ left of r2_, r4_ left of r3_ and size correct.
193 RTC_DCHECK_EQ(r2_ - r1_, r4_ - r3_);
194 // r2_ left of r3.
195 RTC_DCHECK_LT(r2_, r3_);
196}
197
198void SincResampler::InitializeKernel() {
199 // Blackman window parameters.
200 static const double kAlpha = 0.16;
201 static const double kA0 = 0.5 * (1.0 - kAlpha);
202 static const double kA1 = 0.5;
203 static const double kA2 = 0.5 * kAlpha;
204
205 // Generates a set of windowed sinc() kernels.
206 // We generate a range of sub-sample offsets from 0.0 to 1.0.
207 const double sinc_scale_factor = SincScaleFactor(io_sample_rate_ratio_);
208 for (size_t offset_idx = 0; offset_idx <= kKernelOffsetCount; ++offset_idx) {
209 const float subsample_offset =
210 static_cast<float>(offset_idx) / kKernelOffsetCount;
211
212 for (size_t i = 0; i < kKernelSize; ++i) {
213 const size_t idx = i + offset_idx * kKernelSize;
214 const float pre_sinc = static_cast<float>(
215 M_PI * (static_cast<int>(i) - static_cast<int>(kKernelSize / 2) -
216 subsample_offset));
217 kernel_pre_sinc_storage_[idx] = pre_sinc;
218
219 // Compute Blackman window, matching the offset of the sinc().
220 const float x = (i - subsample_offset) / kKernelSize;
221 const float window = static_cast<float>(kA0 - kA1 * cos(2.0 * M_PI * x) +
222 kA2 * cos(4.0 * M_PI * x));
223 kernel_window_storage_[idx] = window;
224
225 // Compute the sinc with offset, then window the sinc() function and store
226 // at the correct offset.
227 kernel_storage_[idx] = static_cast<float>(
228 window * ((pre_sinc == 0)
229 ? sinc_scale_factor
230 : (sin(sinc_scale_factor * pre_sinc) / pre_sinc)));
231 }
232 }
233}
234
235void SincResampler::SetRatio(double io_sample_rate_ratio) {
236 if (fabs(io_sample_rate_ratio_ - io_sample_rate_ratio) <
237 std::numeric_limits<double>::epsilon()) {
238 return;
239 }
240
241 io_sample_rate_ratio_ = io_sample_rate_ratio;
242
243 // Optimize reinitialization by reusing values which are independent of
244 // |sinc_scale_factor|. Provides a 3x speedup.
245 const double sinc_scale_factor = SincScaleFactor(io_sample_rate_ratio_);
246 for (size_t offset_idx = 0; offset_idx <= kKernelOffsetCount; ++offset_idx) {
247 for (size_t i = 0; i < kKernelSize; ++i) {
248 const size_t idx = i + offset_idx * kKernelSize;
249 const float window = kernel_window_storage_[idx];
250 const float pre_sinc = kernel_pre_sinc_storage_[idx];
251
252 kernel_storage_[idx] = static_cast<float>(
253 window * ((pre_sinc == 0)
254 ? sinc_scale_factor
255 : (sin(sinc_scale_factor * pre_sinc) / pre_sinc)));
256 }
257 }
258}
259
260void SincResampler::Resample(size_t frames, float* destination) {
261 size_t remaining_frames = frames;
262
263 // Step (1) -- Prime the input buffer at the start of the input stream.
264 if (!buffer_primed_ && remaining_frames) {
265 read_cb_->Run(request_frames_, r0_);
266 buffer_primed_ = true;
267 }
268
269 // Step (2) -- Resample! const what we can outside of the loop for speed. It
270 // actually has an impact on ARM performance. See inner loop comment below.
271 const double current_io_ratio = io_sample_rate_ratio_;
272 const float* const kernel_ptr = kernel_storage_.get();
273 while (remaining_frames) {
274 // |i| may be negative if the last Resample() call ended on an iteration
275 // that put |virtual_source_idx_| over the limit.
276 //
277 // Note: The loop construct here can severely impact performance on ARM
278 // or when built with clang. See https://codereview.chromium.org/18566009/
279 for (int i = static_cast<int>(
280 ceil((block_size_ - virtual_source_idx_) / current_io_ratio));
281 i > 0; --i) {
282 RTC_DCHECK_LT(virtual_source_idx_, block_size_);
283
284 // |virtual_source_idx_| lies in between two kernel offsets so figure out
285 // what they are.
286 const int source_idx = static_cast<int>(virtual_source_idx_);
287 const double subsample_remainder = virtual_source_idx_ - source_idx;
288
289 const double virtual_offset_idx =
290 subsample_remainder * kKernelOffsetCount;
291 const int offset_idx = static_cast<int>(virtual_offset_idx);
292
293 // We'll compute "convolutions" for the two kernels which straddle
294 // |virtual_source_idx_|.
295 const float* const k1 = kernel_ptr + offset_idx * kKernelSize;
296 const float* const k2 = k1 + kKernelSize;
297
298 // Ensure |k1|, |k2| are 32-byte aligned for SIMD usage. Should always be
299 // true so long as kKernelSize is a multiple of 32.
300 RTC_DCHECK_EQ(0, reinterpret_cast<uintptr_t>(k1) % 32);
301 RTC_DCHECK_EQ(0, reinterpret_cast<uintptr_t>(k2) % 32);
302
303 // Initialize input pointer based on quantized |virtual_source_idx_|.
304 const float* const input_ptr = r1_ + source_idx;
305
306 // Figure out how much to weight each kernel's "convolution".
307 const double kernel_interpolation_factor =
308 virtual_offset_idx - offset_idx;
309 *destination++ =
310 convolve_proc_(input_ptr, k1, k2, kernel_interpolation_factor);
311
312 // Advance the virtual index.
313 virtual_source_idx_ += current_io_ratio;
314
315 if (!--remaining_frames)
316 return;
317 }
318
319 // Wrap back around to the start.
320 virtual_source_idx_ -= block_size_;
321
322 // Step (3) -- Copy r3_, r4_ to r1_, r2_.
323 // This wraps the last input frames back to the start of the buffer.
324 memcpy(r1_, r3_, sizeof(*input_buffer_.get()) * kKernelSize);
325
326 // Step (4) -- Reinitialize regions if necessary.
327 if (r0_ == r2_)
328 UpdateRegions(true);
329
330 // Step (5) -- Refresh the buffer with more input.
331 read_cb_->Run(request_frames_, r0_);
332 }
333}
334
335#undef CONVOLVE_FUNC
336
337size_t SincResampler::ChunkSize() const {
338 return static_cast<size_t>(block_size_ / io_sample_rate_ratio_);
339}
340
341void SincResampler::Flush() {
342 virtual_source_idx_ = 0;
343 buffer_primed_ = false;
344 memset(input_buffer_.get(), 0,
345 sizeof(*input_buffer_.get()) * input_buffer_size_);
346 UpdateRegions(false);
347}
348
349float SincResampler::Convolve_C(const float* input_ptr,
350 const float* k1,
351 const float* k2,
352 double kernel_interpolation_factor) {
353 float sum1 = 0;
354 float sum2 = 0;
355
356 // Generate a single output sample. Unrolling this loop hurt performance in
357 // local testing.
358 size_t n = kKernelSize;
359 while (n--) {
360 sum1 += *input_ptr * *k1++;
361 sum2 += *input_ptr++ * *k2++;
362 }
363
364 // Linearly interpolate the two "convolutions".
365 return static_cast<float>((1.0 - kernel_interpolation_factor) * sum1 +
366 kernel_interpolation_factor * sum2);
367}
368
369} // namespace webrtc
